awd_titl_txt: Endocrine and Immune System Effects on Morphology and       Behavior
awd_abstract_narration: This research project explores the interaction of hormones and                  the immune response in producing reproductive display behaviors                 and specialized morphology such as the rooster's bright red comb.               Testosterone suppresses the immune response in many kinds of                    animals, and Dr. Zuk will examine how the immune system is                      affected by both natural and artificially-induced changes in the                levels of this important hormone.  After challenging male animals               with a parasitic disease, their immune response will be monitored               in the context of the degree of development of sexual                           characteristics and their effect on females.  The research has                  implications for the study of the evolution of reproductive                     behavior because it may bring to light a new mechanism for that                 evolution.
